text:
This stretchy, colorful device was inspired
by octopus skin and brought to you by chemistry.

Researchers at Cornell University developed
this stretchy thing by taking advantage of

what’s called an ionic hydrogel. Hydrogels
are elastic polymers—polyacrylamide in this

case—that are full of water. This one’s
ionic because it’s also got lithium and
chloride ions that allow it to conduct electricity.

These ionic hydrogels serve as electrodes
to feed electrical energy to a stretchy silicone

containing phosphor-doped zinc sulfide that
shines when it’s plugged in. That’s what

The team is already making some pretty unique
soft robots with this stuff, which the researchers

make shine different colors using different
transition metals in the silicone. For instance, adding some

copper gives a green or blue glow, depending
on the metal’s concentration. And manganese

emits yellow light. Mixing these metals gives
white light.

These stretchy composite materials—which
can sense external and internal stimuli—could

open up new ways for people to interact with
robots and display screens, or be used to

create works of art and wearable electronics.
Perhaps one day, we could even don color-changing

skins, just like nature’s chameleon, the
octopus.
